correctAnswer: Horizontal dilation by a factor of 1/3 THEN horizontal shift right 5/3 units THEN vertical dilation by a factor of 7 THEN vertical shift up 5 units
notes: Describe a series of transformations. CRITICAL: There are TWO mathematically equivalent valid answer forms. FORM 1 (given above): Horizontal dilation 1/3 THEN horizontal shift 5/3 units, vertical dilation 7 THEN vertical shift 5 units. FORM 2 (equally correct): Horizontal shift 5 units THEN horizontal dilation 1/3, vertical shift 5/7 units THEN vertical dilation 7. Both forms describe the SAME transformation. Accept either form. Grading rules: Don't be strict about spelling. If they don't include direction of shift, assume up/right for vertical/horizontal. Shift and Translation are both acceptable terms. Dilations must specify the factor. Order of vertical transformations matters, and order of horizontal transformations matters. If student reverses horizontal order (shift before dilation), their shift value should be 5 units (not 5/3). If student reverses vertical order (shift before dilation), their shift value should be 5/7 units (not 5). Both orderings are mathematically equivalent and should be marked CORRECT.

Range of g(θ)=csc(θ/3)+1. csc range is (-∞,-1]∪[1,∞), shift up by 1 gives (-∞,0]∪[2,∞). Accept: (-∞,0]∪[2,∞), (-∞,0]U[2,∞). Must use proper interval notation with ∞ symbol.
Period of h(θ)=3sec(θ)-2. Same as sec(θ), period = 2π. Accept: 2π, 2pi

Vertical asymptotes of h(θ)=3sec(θ)-2 in set-builder notation. sec undefined when cos(θ)=0, so θ=π/2+kπ. Accept: {π/2 + kπ | k ∈ ℤ}, {θ = π/2 + kπ | k ∈ ℤ}, or equivalent. Must use set-builder notation.
Range of h(θ)=3sec(θ)-2. sec range (-∞,-1]∪[1,∞), multiply by 3: (-∞,-3]∪[3,∞), subtract 2: (-∞,-5]∪[1,∞). Accept: (-∞,-5]∪[1,∞), (-∞,-5]U[1,∞). Must use proper interval notation with ∞ symbol.
Period of k(θ)=cot(θ+π/4). cot has period π, horizontal shift doesn't change it. Accept: π, pi

Vertical asymptotes of k(θ)=cot(θ+π/4) in set-builder notation. cot undefined when sin(θ+π/4)=0, so θ+π/4=kπ, θ=-π/4+kπ. Accept: {-π/4 + kπ | k ∈ ℤ}, {kπ - π/4 | k ∈ ℤ}, or equivalent. Must use set-builder notation.
Range of k(θ)=cot(θ+π/4). Same as cot: all real numbers. Accept: (-∞,∞), ℝ, R, (-inf,inf) with proper ∞ symbol.
Simplify sec(θ)·cos(θ). sec=(1/cos), so (1/cos)·cos=1. Accept: 1. Hint: type \theta to get θ.
Simplify cot(θ)·sin(θ). cot=(cos/sin), so (cos/sin)·sin=cos(θ). Accept: cos(θ), cos θ, cosθ. Must use θ, not x or other variable.
Simplify tan(θ)·csc(θ). tan=(sin/cos), csc=(1/sin), so (sin/cos)·(1/sin)=1/cos=sec(θ). Accept: sec(θ), sec θ, secθ. Must use θ.
Simplify sin(θ)·csc(θ)+cos(θ)·sec(θ). sin·csc=1, cos·sec=1, so 1+1=2. Accept: 2
Simplify sec²(θ)-tan²(θ). By identity tan²+1=sec², so sec²-tan²=1. Accept: 1
Simplify csc²(θ)-cot²(θ). By identity cot²+1=csc², so csc²-cot²=1. Accept: 1
Simplify sec²(θ)-1. By identity tan²+1=sec², so sec²-1=tan²(θ). Accept: tan²(θ), tan^2(θ), (tan θ)^2. Must use θ.
Simplify csc²(θ)-1. By identity cot²+1=csc², so csc²-1=cot²(θ). Accept: cot²(θ), cot^2(θ), (cot θ)^2. Must use θ.
Simplify (1-sin²(θ))/cos(θ). By identity 1-sin²=cos², so cos²/cos=cos(θ). Accept: cos(θ), cos θ, cosθ. Must use θ.
True or False: f(θ)=3sin(θ) has range [-3,3]. True - amplitude is 3, so range is [-3,3]. Accept: true, True, T
True or False: g(θ)=sin(2θ) has period 4π. False - period is 2π/2=π, not 4π. Accept: false, False, F
True or False: h(θ)=-5cos(θ) has amplitude -5. False - amplitude is |a|=|-5|=5, always positive. Accept: false, False, F
True or False: f(θ)=2sin(3θ) and g(θ)=2cos(3θ) have the same period. True - both have period 2π/3. Accept: true, True, T
Amplitude of f(θ)=5sin(θ). Amplitude is |a|=5. Accept: 5
Period of f(θ)=5sin(θ). Period is 2π/|b|=2π/1=2π. Accept: 2π, 2pi
Range of f(θ)=5sin(θ). Amplitude 5 means range is [-5,5]. Accept: [-5,5], [-5, 5]
Amplitude of g(θ)=sin(4θ). Amplitude is |a|=1. Accept: 1
Period of g(θ)=sin(4θ). Period is 2π/|b|=2π/4=π/2. Accept: π/2, pi/2
Frequency of g(θ)=sin(4θ). Frequency is |b|/(2π)=4/(2π)=2/π. Accept: 2/π, 2/pi. No decimal approximations.
Amplitude of h(θ)=3cos(2θ). Amplitude is |a|=3. Accept: 3
Period of h(θ)=3cos(2θ). Period is 2π/|b|=2π/2=π. Accept: π, pi
Range of h(θ)=3cos(2θ). Amplitude 3 means range is [-3,3]. Accept: [-3,3], [-3, 3]
Amplitude of g(θ)=2cos(θ/3). Amplitude is |a|=2. Accept: 2
Period of g(θ)=2cos(θ/3). Period is 2π/|b|=2π/(1/3)=6π. Accept: 6π, 6pi
Range of g(θ)=2cos(θ/3). Amplitude 2 means range is [-2,2]. Accept: [-2,2], [-2, 2]
Write sinusoidal f(θ) with amplitude 4, period π. Need |a|=4 and 2π/|b|=π so b=2. Accept: 4sin(2θ), 4cos(2θ), -4sin(2θ), -4cos(2θ), with or without f(θ)= prefix. Must use θ.

Write sinusoidal g(θ) with max 8, min -8, period 6π. Amplitude=(8-(-8))/2=8, midline=0. 2π/|b|=6π so b=1/3. Accept: 8sin(θ/3), 8cos(θ/3), -8sin(θ/3), -8cos(θ/3), with or without g(θ)= prefix. Must use θ.
Write sinusoidal h(θ) with range [-7,7], period 2π/3. Range means amplitude=7. 2π/|b|=2π/3 so b=3. Accept: 7sin(3θ), 7cos(3θ), -7sin(3θ), -7cos(3θ), with or without h(θ)= prefix. Must use θ.
Spring oscillation: displacement ranges -12 to +12 cm. Amplitude is 12. Accept: 12, 12 cm. Units not required.
Spring oscillation: completes one full oscillation every 3 seconds. Period is 3. Accept: 3, 3 seconds. Units not required.

Spring: write d(t)=a cos(bt). At t=0 max displacement so use cos. a=12, period=3 so b=2π/3. Accept: 12cos(2πt/3), d(t)=12cos(2πt/3). MUST use cos (not sin). Accept equivalent forms like 12cos((2π/3)t).
Buoy: height varies -0.5 to +0.5 meters. Amplitude is 0.5. Accept: 0.5, 1/2, 0.5 m. Units not required.
Buoy: completes one full cycle every 4 seconds. Period is 4. Accept: 4, 4 seconds. Units not required.

Buoy: write h(t)=a sin(bt). At t=0 at calm level moving upward so use sin. a=0.5, period=4 so b=π/2. Accept: 0.5sin(πt/2), (1/2)sin(πt/2), h(t)=0.5sin(πt/2). MUST use sin (not cos). Accept equivalent forms.
Rotating wheel h(t)=15sin(4t). Radius equals amplitude = 15. Accept: 15, 15 cm. Units not required.
Rotating wheel h(t)=15sin(4t). Period = 2π/|b| = 2π/4 = π/2. Accept: π/2, pi/2, π/2 seconds. Units not required.
Rotating wheel h(t)=15sin(4t). Max vertical position equals amplitude = 15. Accept: 15, 15 cm. Units not required.
True or False: f(θ)=cos(θ-π/2) has max at θ=π/2. True - cos has max when input=0, so θ-π/2=0 means θ=π/2. Accept: true, True, T
True or False: Period is solely determined by phase shift. False - period is determined by b, not phase shift c. Accept: false, False, F
True or False: If max=8 and min=2, amplitude is 6. False - amplitude=(8-2)/2=3, not 6. Accept: false, False, F
True or False: g(θ)=2cos(θ)+3 has absolute max of 5. True - 2cos ranges [-2,2], so 2cos+3 ranges [1,5]. Accept: true, True, T
Write sinusoidal: amplitude 1, period 2π, midline y=4, max at θ=0. Use cos since max at 0. Accept: cos(θ)+4, cos θ+4, 1cos(θ)+4, any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Write sinusoidal: amplitude 1, period 2π, midline y=0, max at θ=π/4. Phase shift π/4 right. Accept: cos(θ-π/4), any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Write sinusoidal: amplitude 1, period 2π, midline y=5, minimum at θ=π/3. Use -cos since min at phase shift. Accept: -cos(θ-π/3)+5, any equivalent form like cos(θ-π/3-π)+5. Must use θ.
Write sinusoidal: max=4, min=-2, period 2π, max at θ=π/2. Midline=(4-2)/2=1, amplitude=(4-(-2))/2=3, b=1. Accept: 3cos(θ-π/2)+1, 3sin(θ)+1, any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Write sinusoidal: max=7, min=-3, period π, max at θ=π/6. Midline=2, amplitude=5, b=2. Accept: 5cos(2(θ-π/6))+2, 5cos(2θ-π/3)+2, any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Write f(θ) from graph: max (π/2,3), min (3π/2,-1). Midline=1, amplitude=2, period=2π, max at π/2. Accept: 2cos(θ-π/2)+1, 2sin(θ)+1, any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Write g(θ) from graph: max (π/4,2), min (π/2,-4). Midline=-1, amplitude=3, period=π/2 so b=4, max at π/4. Accept: 3cos(4(θ-π/4))-1, 3cos(4θ-π)-1, any equivalent form. Must use θ.
Ferris wheel: radius 25m, center 30m above ground. Min height = 30-25 = 5. Accept: 5, 5 m. Units not required.
Ferris wheel: radius 25m, center 30m above ground. Max height = 30+25 = 55. Accept: 55, 55 m. Units not required.
Ferris wheel: center is 30m above ground, which is the midline. Accept: 30, y=30, 30 m. Units not required.
Ferris wheel: completes one rotation every 2 minutes. Period = 2. Accept: 2, 2 minutes. Units not required.
Ferris wheel: write h(t). Amplitude=25, midline=30, period=2 so b=π, min at t=0 so use -cos. Accept: -25cos(πt)+30, 25cos(πt+π)+30, any equivalent form.
Tide: high=12m, low=4m. Amplitude = (12-4)/2 = 4. Accept: 4, 4 m. Units not required.
Tide: high=12m, low=4m. Midline = (12+4)/2 = 8. Accept: 8, y=8, 8 m. Units not required.
Tide: high at 2AM, low at 8AM. Half-period = 6 hours, so period = 12. Accept: 12, 12 hours. Units not required.
Tide: write d(t) for t hours after midnight. Amplitude=4, midline=8, period=12 so b=π/6, max at t=2. Accept: 4cos((π/6)(t-2))+8, 4cos(πt/6-π/3)+8, any equivalent form.
Let f(θ)=cos(θ). g has 1/3 the period of f, so g has period 2π/3, meaning b=3. Write g in terms of f. Accept: f(3θ), g(θ)=f(3θ).  They can use any variable name here.
Let h(θ)=sin(θ). j has twice the amplitude of h. Write j in terms of h. Accept: 2h(θ), j(θ)=2h(θ).  They can use any variable name here.

Fan blade: 5 rot/sec (period=0.2s), blade 6in from center, center 20in above table, B at max at t=0. Form h(t)=a sin(b(t-c))+d. Student must provide plausible values for a, b, c, d. Key constraints: |a|=6, b=10π, d=20. Phase shift c depends on sign of a. Accept: a=6,b=10π,c=-1/20,d=20 OR a=-6,b=10π,c=1/20,d=20. b must include π (not decimals). Accept fractions or decimals for c.  Shifting over by a period (0.2) is always okay, so if c should be -1/20, it could also be 3/20 or 7/20, etc.

Fan blade continued. Find 5 key points (t,h(t)) for one period of sinusoid. Student must provide plausible coordinates. Expected pattern: max→midline→min→midline→max. Accept ANY valid 5 points on the function, e.g., starting at different t values. Period is 0.2s=1/5s. Points at quarter-periods apart. Accept fractions like (1/20,20) or decimals like (0.05,20). Heights must be 14, 20, or 26.
Fan blade. G=inflection(decreasing), J=minimum. On interval (t_1,t_2) from G to J, is h positive or negative? Function values range 14-26 (all heights above table). Answer: positive.
Fan blade. On interval (G,J) from inflection point to minimum, is h increasing or decreasing? Going from midline (20) down to minimum (14). Answer: decreasing.
Fan blade. On interval (G,J), is h concave up or concave down? Approaching minimum, h''> 0. Answer: concave up. Accept: concave up, up.

Venus orbit: period=225 days, max=108.9 million km, min=107.5 million km, max at t=0. Form D(t)=a cos(b(t-c))+d. Student must provide plausible values. Key: a=0.7, b=2π/225, d=108.2, c=0 (since max at t=0 with cosine). Accept variations in c by adding multiples of period. b must include π (not decimals).

Venus continued. Find 5 key points (t,D(t)). Student must provide plausible coordinates. Pattern: max→midline→min→midline→max. Quarter period = 56.25 days. Accept ANY valid 5 points on the function. Accept fractions like 225/4 for 56.25. Heights must be 107.5, 108.2, or 108.9.
Venus. K=inflection(increasing), P=maximum. On interval (t_1,t_2) from K to P, is D positive or negative? Distances range 108.2-108.9 (all positive). Answer: positive.
Venus. On interval (K,P) from inflection to maximum, is D increasing or decreasing? Going from midline (108.2) up to max (108.9). Answer: increasing.
Venus. On interval (K,P), is D concave up or concave down? Approaching maximum, D''<0. Answer: concave down. Accept: concave down, down.
g(x)=6arcsin(x). Find x such that g(x)=2π. Solution: 6arcsin(x)=2π, arcsin(x)=π/3, x=sin(π/3)=√3/2. Accept: √3/2, sqrt(3)/2, 0.866.
h(x)=6arccos(x)-π. Find x such that h(x)=0. Solution: 6arccos(x)=π, arccos(x)=π/6, x=cos(π/6)=√3/2. Accept: √3/2, sqrt(3)/2, 0.866.
f(x)=4arctan(x), j(x)=-π. Find intersection point. 4arctan(x)=-π, arctan(x)=-π/4, x=-1. Point: (-1,-π). Accept: (-1,-π), (-1, -pi), x=-1 and y=-π.
Solve 2sin(θ)-1=0 on [0,2π). sin(θ)=1/2, θ=π/6,5π/6. Accept: π/6 and 5π/6 in any order, with or without θ=. Accept set notation.
Solve 2cos(θ)+√3=0 on [0,2π). cos(θ)=-√3/2, θ=5π/6,7π/6. Accept: both values in any order, with or without θ=. Accept set notation.
Solve 2sin²(θ)-1=0 on [0,2π). sin²(θ)=1/2, sin(θ)=±√2/2, θ=π/4,3π/4,5π/4,7π/4. Accept: all 4 values in any order. Accept set notation.
Solve sin(2θ)=1/2 on [0,2π). Let u=2θ∈[0,4π). sin(u)=1/2 gives u=π/6,5π/6,13π/6,17π/6. So θ=π/12,5π/12,13π/12,17π/12. Accept all 4 in any order.
Solve cos(θ/2)=-√2/2 on [0,2π). Let u=θ/2∈[0,π). cos(u)=-√2/2 gives u=3π/4. So θ=3π/2. Accept: 3π/2, 3pi/2, θ=3π/2.
Solve 2cos²θ+cosθ-1=0 on [0,2π). Factors: (2cosθ-1)(cosθ+1)=0. cosθ=1/2→θ=π/3,5π/3. cosθ=-1→θ=π. Accept all 3 values in any order.
Solve 4sin²θ-4sinθ-3=0 on [0,2π). Factors: (2sinθ-3)(2sinθ+1)=0. sinθ=3/2 impossible. sinθ=-1/2→θ=7π/6,11π/6. Accept both in any order.
Solve tan²θ-3=0 on [0,2π). tan²θ=3, tanθ=±√3. tanθ=√3→θ=π/3,4π/3. tanθ=-√3→θ=2π/3,5π/3. Accept all 4 in any order.
Solve 2sin²θ+cosθ=1 on [0,2π). Use sin²θ=1-cos²θ: 2cos²θ-cosθ-1=0. (2cosθ+1)(cosθ-1)=0. cosθ=-1/2→θ=2π/3,4π/3. cosθ=1→θ=0. Accept all 3 in any order.
Solve sec²θ+tanθ=1 on [0,2π). Use sec²θ=1+tan²θ: tan²θ+tanθ=0. tanθ(tanθ+1)=0. tanθ=0→θ=0,π. tanθ=-1→θ=3π/4,7π/4. Accept all 4 in any order.
Solve cos²θ-sinθ=1 on [0,2π). Use cos²θ=1-sin²θ: -sin²θ-sinθ=0. sinθ(-sinθ-1)=0. sinθ=0→θ=0,π. sinθ=-1→θ=3π/2. Accept all 3 in any order.
Solve cos(θ)<1/2 on [0,2π]. cos=1/2 at π/3,5π/3. cos<1/2 between them. Answer: (π/3,5π/3). Accept interval notation with parentheses.
Solve sin(θ)≥√2/2 on [0,2π]. sin=√2/2 at π/4,3π/4. sin≥√2/2 between them (inclusive). Answer: [π/4,3π/4]. Accept brackets for closed interval.
Solve sin(θ)<-1/2 on [0,2π]. sin=-1/2 at 7π/6,11π/6. sin<-1/2 between them. Answer: (7π/6,11π/6). Accept interval notation with parentheses.
Simplify (1+tan²θ)/sec²θ. Using 1+tan²θ=sec²θ: sec²θ/sec²θ=1. Accept: 1.
Simplify (csc²θ-1)/csc²θ. csc²θ-1=cot²θ. cot²θ/csc²θ=(cos²θ/sin²θ)/(1/sin²θ)=cos²θ. Accept: cos²θ, cos^2(θ), (cosθ)².
Simplify sin²θ·(1+cot²θ). 1+cot²θ=csc²θ. sin²θ·csc²θ=sin²θ·(1/sin²θ)=1. Accept: 1.
Simplify sinθ·tanθ+cosθ to single trig function. =sin²θ/cosθ+cosθ=(sin²θ+cos²θ)/cosθ=1/cosθ=secθ. Accept: secθ, sec(θ), 1/cosθ.
Simplify (1-cos²θ)/(sinθ·tanθ) to single trig function. =sin²θ/(sin²θ/cosθ)=cosθ. Accept: cosθ, cos(θ).
Simplify cotθ·secθ·sin²θ to single trig function. =(cosθ/sinθ)·(1/cosθ)·sin²θ=sinθ. Accept: sinθ, sin(θ).
Rewrite tan²x using only powers of cos(x). tan²x=sin²x/cos²x=(1-cos²x)/cos²x. Accept: (1-cos²x)/cos²x, 1/cos²x-1, sec²x-1.
Rewrite cotx·cscx using only powers of cos(x). =(cosx/sinx)·(1/sinx)=cosx/sin²x=cosx/(1-cos²x). Accept: cosx/(1-cos²x).
Rewrite secx·tanx using only powers of sin(x). =(1/cosx)·(sinx/cosx)=sinx/cos²x=sinx/(1-sin²x). Accept: sinx/(1-sin²x).
Rewrite cscx-sinx using only powers of sin(x). =1/sinx-sinx=(1-sin²x)/sinx. Accept: (1-sin²x)/sinx, cos²x/sinx.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of buses that arrive on time is 85%
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Transit claims 85% on-time, commuter suspects lower. Must include population language ('true proportion', 'all buses'). Accept: 85%, 0.85.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of buses that arrive on time is less than 85%
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. One-sided (<) since commuter suspects lower. Must include population language. Accept: less than, below, lower than, <.

correctAnswer: μ, the true mean sodium content per serving
notes: Identify parameter. Label says 180mg, group thinks higher. Accept: mu or μ. Description should mention mean/average sodium.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu = 180, μ=180. H0: label not required.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Group believes higher. Accept: mu > 180. Ha: label not required.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of loot boxes that contain a rare item is 1/20
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Company claims 1 in 20 has rare item. Must include population language. Accept: 1/20, 5%, 0.05.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of loot boxes that contain a rare item is not 1/20
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. Two-sided (≠) since player suspects 'different'. Must include population language. Accept: not 1/20, not 5%, different from, ≠.

correctAnswer: μ, the true mean time to graduate
notes: Identify parameter. University claims 4 years, parents suspect longer. Accept: mu or μ. Description should mention mean/average graduation time.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu = 4, μ=4.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Parents suspect longer. Accept: mu > 4.

correctAnswer: There is no difference in the proportion of pets that remain flea-free between the new medication and the standard treatment
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Comparing two treatments for flea effectiveness. Must include population language and convey 'no difference'. Verbal form required.

correctAnswer: The proportion of pets that remain flea-free is higher for the new medication than for the standard treatment
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. One-sided (>) since testing if new is better. Must include population language. Verbal form required.

correctAnswer: μ, the true mean assembly time after installing the new equipment
notes: Identify parameter. Was 12 min before, manager thinks decreased. Accept: mu or μ. Should mention mean/average assembly time.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu = 12, μ=12.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Manager believes time decreased. Accept: mu < 12.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of voter turnout in the county is 62%
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Analyst checking if county differs from statewide 62%. Must include population language. Accept: 62%, 0.62.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of voter turnout in the county is not 62%
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. Two-sided (≠) since checking if 'differs'. Must include population language. Accept: not 62%, different from 62%.

correctAnswer: μ, the true mean wait time at this location
notes: Identify parameter. Coffee chain advertises 3 min, detective suspects longer at particular location. Accept: mu or μ. Should mention mean/average wait time.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu = 3, μ=3.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Detective suspects longer wait. Accept: mu > 3.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of patients who experience drowsiness with the new medication is 8%
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Testing if new medication causes drowsiness at different rate than placebo (8%). Must include population language. Accept: 8%, 0.08.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of patients who experience drowsiness with the new medication is not 8%
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. Two-sided (≠) since testing for 'different rate'. Must include population language. Accept: not 8%, different from 8%.

correctAnswer: μ₁ - μ₂, the difference in true mean exam scores between students who take handwritten notes and students who take laptop notes
notes: Identify parameter. Researcher believes handwritten notes lead to higher scores. Group 1 = handwritten, Group 2 = laptop. Accept: mu1 - mu2, μ₁ - μ₂. Description should mention difference in means.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu1 - mu2 = 0, μ₁ - μ₂ = 0, mu_1 - mu_2 = 0.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Researcher believes handwritten (group 1) scores higher. Accept: mu1 - mu2 > 0, μ₁ - μ₂ > 0.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of rides that receive a 5-star rating is 90%
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Ride-sharing claims 90% 5-star, driver suspects lower. Must include population language. Accept: 90%, 0.90.

correctAnswer: The true proportion of rides that receive a 5-star rating is less than 90%
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. One-sided (<) since driver suspects lower. Must include population language. Accept: less than 90%, below 90%.

correctAnswer: μ₁ - μ₂, the difference in true mean spending between customers who receive free shipping and customers who pay for shipping
notes: Identify parameter. Testing if free shipping customers spend more. Group 1 = free shipping, Group 2 = paid shipping. Accept: mu1 - mu2, μ₁ - μ₂. Description should mention difference in means/spending.
Null hypothesis symbolic. Accept: mu1 - mu2 = 0, μ₁ - μ₂ = 0, mu_1 - mu_2 = 0.
Alternative hypothesis symbolic. Testing if free shipping (group 1) spends more. Accept: mu1 - mu2 > 0, μ₁ - μ₂ > 0.
Consumer group concludes boxes are underfilled. They rejected H0, so Type I error is possible. Accept: Type I, Type 1, I, 1.
Researcher concludes insufficient evidence fertilizer helps. Failed to reject H0, so Type II error is possible. Accept: Type II, Type 2, II, 2.
Engineer concludes defect rate is too high. Rejected H0, so Type I error is possible. Accept: Type I, Type 1, I, 1.
Pollster reports insufficient evidence support differs from 50%. Failed to reject H0, so Type II error is possible. Accept: Type II, Type 2, II, 2.
Null hypothesis for coin bias test. Accept: p = 0.5, p = 0.50, p = 1/2.
Alternative hypothesis for coin biased toward heads. One-sided (>). Accept: p > 0.5, p > 0.50, p > 1/2.
If coin is fair, probability of incorrectly concluding biased = α = 0.05. Accept: 0.05, 5%, .05.
Rejecting H0 when H0 is true is Type I error. Accept: Type I, Type 1, I, 1.
If true rate is 2% (H0 true), probability of incorrectly concluding exceeds 2% = α = 0.01. Accept: 0.01, 1%, .01.
True rate is 5% (Ha true) but failed to reject H0 = Type II error. Accept: Type II, Type 2, II, 2.
Using larger α (0.05 vs 0.01) increases power. Larger α = more lenient cutoff = easier to reject H0. Accept: increase, increases, go up, higher.

correctAnswer: If the drug actually reduces cholesterol more than the placebo, there is an 80% probability the study will detect this effect
notes: Explain 80% power in context. Must convey: IF Ha is true (drug works), 80% chance of correctly rejecting H0 (detecting the effect). Accept variations that capture this meaning.
Sample size 100 to 400: power increases. Larger n = smaller SE = easier to detect effects. Accept: increases, increase, goes up, higher.
α from 0.05 to 0.01: power decreases. Smaller α = stricter cutoff = harder to reject H0. Accept: decreases, decrease, goes down, lower.
True effect size increases: power increases. Larger effect = alternative distribution farther from null = easier to detect. Accept: increases, increase, goes up, higher.

correctAnswer: The proportion of customers who make a purchase is the same with or without the new advertisement
notes: Null hypothesis verbal. Ad test. Must convey no difference/no effect. Accept: proportion unchanged, ad has no effect, no increase in purchases.

correctAnswer: The new advertisement increases the proportion of customers who make a purchase
notes: Alternative hypothesis verbal. One-sided (>). Must convey ad increases purchases. Accept: proportion is higher with ad, ad improves purchase rate.

correctAnswer: Concluding the advertisement increases purchases when it actually does not
notes: Type I error in context. Rejecting H0 when H0 true. Must convey: falsely concluding ad works when it doesn't. Accept variations.
Probability of Type I error = α = 0.02. Accept: 0.02, 2%, .02.

correctAnswer: Failing to detect that the advertisement works when it actually does increase purchases
notes: Type II error in context. Failing to reject H0 when Ha true. Must convey: missing a real effect, concluding no evidence when ad actually works. Accept variations.

correctAnswer: Type I error probability stays the same (0.02), Type II error probability decreases

T/F: A 95% CI means there is a 95% probability that the true parameter is in the interval. FALSE - The parameter is fixed; the 95% refers to the method's long-run success rate. Accept: False, F, false.
T/F: If we repeated sampling many times, about 95% of 95% CIs would contain the true parameter. TRUE - This is the correct interpretation. Accept: True, T, true.
T/F: A 99% CI is wider than a 95% CI (same sample). TRUE - Higher confidence requires larger critical value, hence wider interval. Accept: True, T, true.
T/F: Increasing sample size makes the CI wider. FALSE - Larger n decreases SE, making interval narrower. Accept: False, F, false.
T/F: The CI is centered at the sample proportion p̂. TRUE - Formula is p̂ ± ME. Accept: True, T, true.
95% CI is (0.35, 0.41). Claim: true proportion < 0.30. Entire interval is above 0.30, so evidence AGAINST. Accept: Against, against.
95% CI is (0.35, 0.41). Claim: true proportion > 0.30. Entire interval is above 0.30, so evidence FOR. Accept: For, for.

95% CI is (0.35, 0.41). Claim: true proportion = 0.38. 0.38 is inside interval, so data is CONSISTENT. Accept: Consistent, consistent, plausible.
n=400 gives ME=5%. Want ME=2.5%. ME ∝ 1/√n, so halving ME requires 4× sample size. n = 4×400 = 1600. Accept: 1600.
90% CI from n=1000 has width W. 90% CI from n=4000 has width Z. Width ∝ 1/√n. Z/W = √(1000/4000) = √(1/4) = 0.5. Accept: 0.5, 1/2, 0.50.
Poll: 57% support candidate, ME=±3%. Lower bound = 57 - 3 = 54%. Accept: 54, 54%, 0.54.
Poll: 57% support candidate, ME=±3%. Upper bound = 57 + 3 = 60%. Accept: 60, 60%, 0.60.
Poll CI is (54%, 60%). Does interval include 50%? NO - entire interval is above 50%. Accept: No, no.
Poll CI is (54%, 60%). Can we conclude majority support? YES - entire interval is above 50%. Accept: Yes, yes.
Rank narrowest to widest. A: 90% n=400, B: 95% n=400, C: 95% n=900. Width ∝ z*/√n. C has largest n, A has smallest z*. Order: C, A, B. Accept: C, A, B or CAB or C A B.
Using 95% CI (0.52, 0.68), reject H₀: p=0.50 at α=0.05? 0.50 is NOT in interval, so YES reject. Accept: Yes, yes.
Using 99% CI (0.48, 0.72), reject H₀: p=0.50 at α=0.01? 0.50 IS in interval, so NO don't reject. Accept: No, no.
Fill blank: The ___ is calculated using hypothesized p₀ and measures exact spread. Answer: SD (standard deviation). Accept: SD, standard deviation.
Fill blank: The ___ is calculated using sample statistic p̂ because we don't know true parameter. Answer: SE (standard error). Accept: SE, standard error.
Fill blank: The ___ is half the width of a CI. Answer: MoE (margin of error). Accept: MoE, ME, margin of error.
Fill blank: In a hypothesis test, we use the ___ to calculate the z-score. Answer: SD. Accept: SD, standard deviation.
Fill blank: In a CI, we use the ___ to calculate the margin of error. Answer: SE. Accept: SE, standard error.

correctAnswer: The normal approximation is not valid
notes: If np̂ < 10, what problem does this create? The normal approximation to the sampling distribution is not valid, so the CI formula doesn't work properly.  Be pretty lenient here.
